subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?
msgSnippet: Simple methods break, too. As posted last time this discussion went around the exact same circles: public class Foo { private int d_i = 0; private int d_j = 0;
messageBody:
Simple methods break, too. As posted last time this discussion went around
the exact same circles:

public class Foo
{
private int d_i = 0;
private int d_j = 0;

// ... other stuff

public void setI(int i) {d_i = i;}
public int getI() {return i;}

public void setJ(int j) {d_j = j;}
public int getJ() {return d_i;}

// .. More other stuff
} // class Foo

This code is trivial. It is also wrong. Somebody probably created the
accessors for i and then cut and paste them for j without editting
everywhere they should. Without a testcase here, there will be a more
complex failure somewhere else. Somebody will spend an hour or so pulling
their hair out. A testcase for this is very quick to do. It also has the
side effect of making sure things still work after someone changes one of
the accessors to return a computed value and forgets to add the test. The
point of regression is to catch problems that arise from someone who makes
a change forgetting to do everything they should.

Most bugs are trivial mistakes. Most people pay attention when coding
complex things and suspect the complex code when something goes wrong.
When people write trivial or repetitive code, their attention drifts and
they make mistakes. The trivial code also happens to be the last place
someone looks for the mistake, as evidenced by this discussion.

On Fri, 21 Dec 2001, STRAYER, JON (AIT) wrote:

> Do you test that 1 + 1 = 2 just in case the compiler makes a mistake? Then
> why test a simple getter? Sure, if the value returned is calculated then
> test it. If the value stored is the result of some calculation then test
> it. But that's not what was presented.
>
> > To this I would respond that most bugs are introduced as unforeseen
> > consequences of modification to existing code. There may be
> > interdependencies that we weren't aware of. Most bugs seem
> > obvious once they're discovered.
>
>
> int getFoo() {return foo;}
>
> What kind of interdependencies are there going to be?
>
>
> > And besides testing get methodds are generally pretty darn easy. In
> > response to the question "Why do it?" I say "Why not do it?"
>
> What does the buy you?
